user: What is margin and free margin?
standard_answer: Margin is the required deposit to open a leveraged position. It's calculated as: Position Size ÷ Leverage. Free Margin is the amount available to open new positions, calculated as: Equity - Used Margin. When Free Margin reaches zero, you cannot open new trades. If Margin Level falls below 100%, you may receive a margin call warning.

user: What happens during a margin call?
standard_answer: A margin call occurs when your Margin Level falls below 100%, meaning your losses are approaching your available margin. You'll receive a warning to either deposit more funds or close some positions to reduce risk. If Margin Level reaches 50% (Stop Out level), the system will automatically start closing your losing positions to protect your account from further losses.

user: How do I read forex charts?

Green/white candles indicate price increases, red/black candles show decreases. Start with basic chart reading before using advanced technical analysis.

user: What is slippage in trading?
standard_answer: Slippage occurs when your trade is executed at a different price than expected, usually during high volatility or low liquidity periods. For example, if you place a buy order at 1.1000 but it executes at 1.1002, that's 2 pips of slippage. While slippage cannot be completely avoided, HFM's fast execution and deep liquidity help minimize it.

user: What is a pip in forex?
standard_answer: A pip (percentage in point) is the smallest price movement in a currency pair, typically the fourth decimal place. For most pairs like EUR/USD, 1 pip = 0.0001. For JPY pairs, 1 pip = 0.01. Pips are used to measure price changes and calculate profits/losses. For example, if EUR/USD moves from 1.1000 to 1.1010, that's a 10-pip movement.

user: How do I calculate profit and loss?
standard_answer: Profit/Loss = (Close Price - Open Price) × Position Size × Pip Value. For buy positions, profit occurs when close price > open price. For sell positions, profit occurs when close price < open price. Your trading platform automatically calculates P&L in real-time. Remember to account for spread costs when calculating net profit.

user: What is hedging in forex?
standard_answer: Hedging involves opening opposite positions to reduce risk exposure. For example, if you're long EUR/USD, you might short EUR/GBP to hedge against EUR weakness.
